Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. Actin filaments are also the main components of stress fibers, which are the main contractile elements of cells. Actin filaments are connected to each other by a protein called cofilin. Cofilin is the main regulator of the disassembly of stress fibers. Here, we show that cofilin can also disassemble highly connected actin filament networks. We show that this disassembly is enhanced by a mechanical torque that cofilin induces in the filament network. We propose that this mechanism is critical for the disassembly of highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanism is important for cells to change their shape and to contract.

The ribosome is the central protein–RNA complex responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into proteins. The ribosome is able to read mRNA codons and translate them into amino acids, but the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. We find that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. Here, we use a quantitative approach to test the role of the aquatic environment in driving the evolution of body size in mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with the aquatic environment driving and confining body size evolution toward a size attractor.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The virus responsible, rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. Here we show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of new antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. The pili-mediated surface sensing system is important for the pathogen because it allows it to regulate its virulence and biofilm-inducing gene expression. This system is also important for the host because it allows the pathogen to sense surfaces on short timescales, which can help the host to respond to the pathogen. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a common species in North America. We also show that the virus can spread between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The domestication of chickens is one of the most important events in the history of mankind. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present a detailed faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the global carbon cycle. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state, and yet the system can change its critical state to a noncritical state by some external stimulus. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The temperature of the surface environment has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface environment in turn is influenced by the temperature of the deep interior of the planet. Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does so is unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the neural basis of phrase construction. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. The merge operation was not limited to simple sequences of words but applied equally to multiword phrases. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probability, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Activity in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first study to show that the brain can build syntactic structures. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the nature of language and language acquisition. They also have implications for the design of language-based brain-computer interfaces.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development. Axin is a key component of the signaling pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for the development of new treatments for obesity. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under increasing pressure from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate this pressure. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The origin of life is one of the most important and enigmatic problems in biology. The RNA world hypothesis proposes that life on Earth evolved from an RNA-based prebiotic world. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. This polymerase ribozyme can now be used to reconstruct the RNA world in the laboratory. The polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can serve as a building block for the construction of an RNA-based cell. This work represents a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results provide a new way to study the physical dynamics of cities. They also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of cities. This work is important for understanding the physical dynamics of cities and for the design of policies to improve the physical appearance of neighborhoods.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is still in the early stage. The current treatment mainly focuses on the treatment of symptoms. In this study, we found that the treatment of tocilizumab can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a foundation for further investigation of the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the development of new antifungal agents. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly related to the evolutionary history of the species. Our findings can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to colitis pathogenesis by two distinct mechanisms. First, Th17 cells can directly transition to Th1-like cells and contribute to disease. Second, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is expressed in the gut in response to infection with the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall polymer, altering the permeability of the gut and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings reveal a mechanism by which a pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiota and may inform the development of novel vector control strategies. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short-tailed bird group Pygostylia is a key group for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching members of Pygostylia obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by these basal taxa. With wings having a low aspect ratio and wing loading, Jinguofortis may have been adapted particularly to dense forest environments. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases our knowledge of the early evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian bauplan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the evolution of our climate.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can be used to communicate with conspecifics, to hide from predators, or to attract mates. The color of an animal is also important for its camouflage, which is essential for its survival in nature. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) can be modified by the presence of blue-green tissues. We also describe a new mechanism for the evolution of this color, which is likely to be common in vertebrates. This mechanism is based on the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is responsible for the green color of anurans. This discovery has important implications for the understanding of the evolution of color and camouflage in vertebrates. It also has implications for the study of the evolution of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most diverse group of proteins in vertebrates.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We analyzed 467 samples from 72 pocket Bibles and 293 additional samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1991) on finite games. Our result is also a step toward the study of repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are widely used in chemistry. However, there is no pressure-dependent version of these properties. Here, we introduce pressure-dependent versions of electronegativity and chemical hardness, which are shown to decrease with pressure. We show that these properties can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena under pressure. This work opens the door to the study of pressure-dependent chemistry.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in climate change is poorly understood. We quantify the effect of changes in human demography on fire activity and its impact on climate. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, this effect is uncertain and depends on socioeconomic trajectory and emissions scenario. Our results highlight the importance of active and passive fire suppression in driving future fire regimes. This study emphasizes the need to consider fire in climate policy.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by hemocytes from the squid’s immune cells, just before dusk, and is catabolized by the symbionts, whose activity is dependent on the timing of this nutrient delivery. This glycan is thus used by the squid to regulate the growth of its symbionts, which in turn are required for the squid to produce light at night. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis by the provision of nutrients. It also suggests that other hosts may use similar strategies to control the activities of their symbionts. (Show more)

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe, after which it established itself in rodents. Here, we show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors. We find that the introduction of plague into Europe was repeated over a period of 15 ± 1 y, with the bacterium being reintroduced into Europe from Asia. This result challenges the current understanding of the history of the second plague pandemic. It also suggests that the introduction of plague into Europe was not the singular event that is generally assumed. This in turn has implications for the understanding of the history of the pandemic and the development of plague control measures. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, the population dynamics of asteroids are poorly understood. Here, we show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the wasting disease that has caused the recent decline in asteroid populations.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML remains poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. Here we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that the antibodies can achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our results may lead to the development of novel and more efficient therapies for AML. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide information on the status of crops across the country, which is used by farmers, policy makers, and the general public. We show that this probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results have implications for the way we monitor and manage agricultural production, and can be extended to other crops and countries.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. Here, we present a synthesis of the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. The origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes are key questions in the origin of life. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a major event in the evolution of life on Earth. The first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, was detonated in the New Mexico desert on 16 July 1945. The explosion created a fireball, shock wave, and a crater, as well as a 50-m-tall tower of sand, copper, and other materials. The tower was later excavated, and the material was found to be a glassy mixture of sand, copper, and other materials. We report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in this material. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed by a nuclear explosion, has implications for the search for extraterrestrial materials. It also demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed by extreme pressure–temperature conditions, which are common in the Earth’s crust. This discovery has implications for the search for quasicrystals in the Earth’s crust. Finally, the discovery of this quasicrystal in red trinitite has implications for the search for extraterrestrial materials.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. ASK1-deficient microglia/macrophages exhibited reduced neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in glial cells and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. This work has important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. The mechanisms that govern the spread of these aggregates are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading and pathology in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for the development of new therapeutic strategies. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic and many of them were small and simple. The study of the aquatic flowering plants of the Cretaceous period, such as Montsechia, is important for understanding the early evolution of the flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that cause a variety of diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of humans from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the human parvovirus B19 lineage occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level has risen over the last 25 y, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of global warming and the natural variability of the climate system. The acceleration is not due to human activities.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We find that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader pattern of decline in the quality of life for those born after 1950.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical component of enzyme design and drug discovery. However, the structure of the enzyme–product complex is often more informative, as it reveals the fate of the substrate and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This detailed, chemically informative structure is critical for understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. The results also have implications for the design of inhibitors that target the intermediate. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe emerging coronavirus infection that causes high mortality. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment initiated 12 h postinoculation provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and activity of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by host hemocytes into the symbiotic crypts just before dusk, when the squid is ready to receive the glycan. Chitin catabolism by the symbionts is required for a periodic acidification of the crypts, which increases the level of oxygen available to the symbionts and enhances their capacity to produce bioluminescence at night. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbionts in their host’s tissues. It also suggests that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their associated microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in the habitat of the symbionts. This may be a general mechanism for the regulation of symbiosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions and a boost in students’ respect for teachers. These findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can cause transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional mutagenesis remains unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcriptional fidelity. We found that the minor-groove alkylation can cause transcriptional stalling, whereas the major-groove alkylation can cause GMP misincorporation. The minor-groove alkylation can also modulate the transcriptional lesion bypass route. Our study provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanism of transcriptional mutagenesis. This work also provides a potential strategy for the development of DNA alkylation-based cancer therapy. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. Virions require spike (S) proteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. Here, we show that the first cleavages are significant for virus infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant for virus virulence. Therefore, the first cleavages may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Understanding the determinants of MERS-CoV virulence may lead to the development of more effective therapies and vaccines. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals in catering settings could have a significant impact on reducing these emissions. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a large impact on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This study also shows that the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available is concentrated among diners who are already choosing vegetarian meals. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available could have a large impact on the health of the population while also reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This study provides evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a major component of this interface. Here we use a combination of methods to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the surfaceome of cancer cells. The surfaceome is a promising target for drug and biomarker discovery. Vote-by-mail is a popular policy to protect the integrity of the electoral process during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes are unclear. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the COVID-19 pandemic.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The virus has a large number of accessory proteins that are rapidly evolving, and it is unclear how these proteins contribute to the severity of the disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is likely important for immune evasion and immune suppression. The structure also reveals a second interface that is not present in SARS-CoV, suggesting that the two viruses have evolved different strategies to evade the immune system. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The world is full of associations. We are interested in finding the strongest ones. Unfortunately, we can only search for the strongest associations. This means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant an association that we find. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help to make the world a better place.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells remains a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the differentiation of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in vivo. These results indicate that ETV2 is a promising factor for the generation of ECs. Furthermore, ETV2 can be used for the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells, such as fibroblasts, and for the formation of vascular networks in vivo. These findings provide a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the formation of vascular networks. Thus, the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that zebrafish augmentor ligands play an important role in pigment development. We demonstrate that zebrafish augmentor ligands are essential for embryonic iridophore development and adult body coloration. Importantly, these processes are entirely mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the role of augmentor ligands in normal development and for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the treatment of T2D is still a challenge. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO β-cells. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential target for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The evolution of these lineages is not well understood. Here, we identified a mechanism that limits the reassortment of influenza A virus lineages. We identified a sequence-dependent interaction between two viral RNA segments. This interaction is required for the selective packaging of the viral genome. We propose that this mechanism limits the reassortment of influenza A virus lineages.

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving multiple factors. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is one of the most important factors. However, the mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Our study provides a molecular mechanism for the atheroprone hemodynamic environment and a potential therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a molecular basis for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, increasing the risk of wildfire to people and property. This expansion has been driven by the use of fire by humans, which has increased the availability of fuel and the ability to start fires. This work provides a quantitative assessment of the role of humans in expanding the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Our results highlight the importance of reducing the risk of wildfire to people and property and the need to manage human-caused wildfires to reduce the risk of wildfire to ecosystems. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of humans in expanding the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire to people and property should be a focus of United States policy. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results provide a new way to study the physical dynamics of cities. They also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of cities. This work is important for understanding the physical dynamics of cities and for the design of policies to improve the physical appearance of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropod pests remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests and a foundation for the rational design of insect control strategy. It should also help in conserving biodiversity. The Zika virus (ZIKV) has been linked to a variety of severe health problems, including microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome. The mechanisms of these diseases are not fully understood, but the virus is thought to be transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and spread from person to person through sexual contact. Here we use a mathematical model to investigate the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We find that the virus is cleared from the body within 5 d in most cases, but that the time to clearance can be reduced by antiviral treatment. We also find that the virus is cleared more quickly when the treatment is given prophylactically than when it is given after the onset of symptoms. These results suggest that antiviral treatment may be effective in reducing the severity of the disease. However, more research is needed to confirm this and to understand the mechanisms of the disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most important factors driving the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is the increased frequency of mass bleaching events. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts play a crucial role in the onset of bleaching. We identify altered nutrient cycling as a key driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis, which will lead to the loss of the coral reef ecosystem. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help to conserve this unique and valuable ecosystem. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to systemic infections and organ failure. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome, which in turn can promote tumor growth. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbiome homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, which is relevant to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. The response to chemotherapy is poor in patients with breast cancer, and the mechanisms underlying this resistance are not fully understood. Here we show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with an antibody enhances the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. This approach may also be applicable to other types of cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, a small volcano in West Antarctica. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which, in turn, likely caused a shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a change in the circulation pattern over the Southern Hemisphere. This shift is consistent with the start of accelerated deglaciation. This study highlights the importance of volcanic eruptions in the Southern Hemisphere, which have been overlooked in the past. The findings also have implications for the role of volcanic forcing in the past and for the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of ecosystem services. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that fishing pressure is highest in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to inform the design of policies to protect the role of rivers in providing food and employment for poor and undernourished populations. Our results highlight the importance of inland fisheries in global food security and biodiversity conservation.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost during development, and the adult nervous system is incapable of regenerating. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is similar to a form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in the study of neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study unifies disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work may lead to the development of new strategies for regenerating the adult nervous system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired. It is essential for the proper development of the organism and the maintenance of genetic diversity. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, which are interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the general pattern of recombination described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This work provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of recombination in humans.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a small number of reproducible networks, which are assumed to represent the main functional systems of the brain. However, the total activity of the brain is not fluctuating, and the analysis of metabolic signals can provide a more complete picture of brain activity. Here, we show that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the DMN, but that this pattern is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. The dominant RSN is also reduced in cognitive and motor dysfunction in PD, and is reduced earlier in PD than in Alzheimer’s disease. These results suggest that metabolic imaging can provide information about the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach may be useful for the early diagnosis and monitoring of disease progression.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the most studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification of transfer RNAs. In this study, we identify a 5′ NAD+ cap in yeast. We also show that this cap is not found on all NAD+ modified mRNAs. This suggests that the 5′ NAD+ cap may play a role in the regulation of mRNA metabolism.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The results also suggest that epigenetic alterations at specific loci may be a marker of the metabolic memory effect. The findings may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. This article is protected by copyright. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Thus, our study provides a potential therapeutic target for TNBC. This article is protected by copyright.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study opens new perspectives for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds. The biosynthesis of many of these compounds is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous compounds to the overall aroma of tomato fruit is poorly understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles from their corresponding precursors. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be a valuable resource for the improvement of tomato flavor. Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a critical insight for understanding the impacts of climate change on the functioning of ecosystems. It also has implications for the design of biodiversity conservation strategies. The maintenance of biodiversity is not only important for maintaining ecosystem services, but also for ensuring that ecosystems can adapt to environmental change. Our results suggest that this adaptation will be compromised if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, as well as the direction of the animal’s head and the orientation of its body. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a novel approach to study the organization of MEC in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. Our results suggest that the organization of MEC is more complex than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study illustrates how a parasite may synchronize its flowering with that of its host.

The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is the primary circuit for the control of movement and motivation. Here, we describe a specialized subsystem of the nigrostriatal system that is formed by striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes. These bouquet-like formations, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are highly specialized integrative units that receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Given the importance of dopamine in health and disease, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to the control of movement and motivation. Understanding their structure and function could lead to new insights into the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others. In this work, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust signal of connection. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connection with them. This signal is also used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of our connection with others. Thus, this signal may be a universal way for us to understand and be understood.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are characterized by the presence of specialized ion channels in the plasma membrane and internal Ca2+ stores. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells. STIM1 is expressed in SAN cells and is required for the maintenance of the SAN function. STIM1 regulates the activity of ion channels in SAN cells, including a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms governing the function of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, in wild-type rice plants but not in plants with reduced jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis or perception. This interaction between Si and JA is mediated by the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice against insect herbivores by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides a new mechanism for the use of Si as a biocontrol agent and may also have implications for the use of Si in agriculture. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. Furthermore, we show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results suggest that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a potential target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This mechanism is distinct from other forms of memory in that it does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This mechanism is suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. We believe that this mechanism is a useful addition to the toolbox of computational models of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNA is a major challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient inputs from small tributaries are often overlooked in assessments of coastal eutrophication. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies. We found that small tributaries delivered ∼20% of the daily nutrient loads to Lake Michigan, but ∼50% of the dissolved inorganic nutrients. This suggests that small tributaries may be a significant driver of coastal algal blooms in large water bodies. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and the need to address them in future management efforts.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare configurations of its degrees of freedom. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of robust chemical systems.

The mechanisms by which the NMDA receptor is targeted by autoantibodies in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can alter the dynamics of cortical microcircuits, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of action of other types of autoantibodies in autoimmune encephalitis. This work may also have implications for the development of new therapies for autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system. However, the history of the last 500 million years is poorly understood because of the scarcity of high-resolution, multiproxy records. Here, we present a high-resolution record of a global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that the event was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These results have implications for the history of the Earth system and for the development of future climate models. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to the protection of remaining forest. These findings are important for the future of sustainability certification in the palm oil sector.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual can have a profound effect on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, and the sex of the offspring is determined by the sex of the parent. In species with multiple loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent and the sex of the offspring. Here we investigate the effects of multiple loci on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with four possible sex classes.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by reactive oxygen species and degraded by photochemical reactions. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in retinal pigment epithelial cells, promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. The results also suggest that the addition of iron chelators to current therapies for age-related macular degeneration may be beneficial. This is an important step toward the development of new therapies for this blinding disease. (Show more)

Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, can evolve into specialists on different prey types. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. This perspective is important for understanding the structure and functioning of marine ecosystems.

The human hand is a remarkable structure, with a suite of features that are unique to us and that are absent in all other primates. The origin of these features is a matter of intense debate, but the fossil record has thus far failed to provide unambiguous evidence for the evolution of the key features of the human hand. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key feature of the human hand that is absent in all other primates. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key feature of the human hand. The discovery of this fossil also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and its relationship to the Neandertal hand. This article is protected by copyright. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One-carbon units are essential for cell growth, and are provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic deficiency of cancer cells that can be targeted therapeutically. This work provides a rationale for the use of formate as a metabolic targeting agent in cancer. Formate is a by-product of fermentation, and thus the use of formate in cancer therapy may be applicable to a broad range of cancers. Formate is also a precursor for the biosynthesis of the antibiotic valinomycin, which is used in the fuel cells of the future. Thus, formate may be a useful antibiotic for the treatment of cancer in the future.

The world is facing a triple crisis of hunger, malnutrition, and environmental degradation. Agricultural intensification is a key strategy to address these challenges, but it is often at the expense of natural landscapes such as forests. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s access to fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of micronutrients. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase access to these foods, thus improving people’s diets. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and nutrition security. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in strategies to improve food and nutrition security. This is particularly important in low- and middle-income countries where forests are often overlooked in such strategies.

Modern farm machinery is the key to the success of agriculture, but it has also contributed to the loss of soil productivity. We show that the weight of modern farm vehicles has increased the mechanical stress in the subsoil to levels that are close to the safe limits for soil functioning. This has resulted in the widespread subsoil compaction, with potential loss of productivity. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods on land may have had similar adverse effects on soil productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have implications for the design of farm machinery and for the study of prehistoric ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
